oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter of Administration Regarding Estate of Roberts, Daniel R.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The document indicates that since Dr. Daniel R. Roberts has died, his estate will be passed on to Jaine Roberts. It is signed by an individual named Bronson. It also indicates that a inventory of his possessions must be taken.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marriage Certificate of Thomas, Robert and Richards, Anne, 1868-07-14
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The one-sided, black-and-white document is a Certificate of Marriage documenting the union between Robert Thomas and Anne Richards. The document indicates that both resided in Steuben, New York. It certifies that Morris J. Williams of the Morris J. Williams Baptist Ministry married the pair on 1968-07-14 in the Remsen Village. Evan Roberts and Jane Roberts, who both resided in Remsen, New York, acted as witnesses at the wedding. The document was created on 1969-03-23 in Trenton, New York, more commonly known as Barneveld, New York. Morris J. Williams signed the document. A pictoral depiction of a marriage ceremony is pictured above the text.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Oneida County, New York State
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Marriage certificates; Documents
Community & Events
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: document; b&w; 14.5 x 12 in. (36.83 x 30.48 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To the best of their knowledge, all copyrights are owned by the Remsen Steuben Historical Society. Contact the Remsen Steuben Historical Society for information regarding reproduction of these images.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Certificate of American Citizenship, Roberts, William D., 1939-06-10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The one-sided, black-and-white document is a certificate that certifies that William D. Roberts is considered to be a citizen of the United States of America. Roberts had to agree to renounce the queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland before he could become a citizen, given he was formerly a Welsh citizen.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Oneida County, State of New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Citizenship; Documents
People

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wartime Correspondence From Wilder, Henry B. to Roberts, William D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The letter is written by Wilder, Henry B. to Roberts, William D. Wilder. Wilder responds to Roberts' inquiry regarding Daniel's wages. He also notes that Daniel is the "same as before." Wilder inquires to Roberts about where William is and what he is doing.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marble Headstone Receipt, Utica, New York, 1863-07-22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The receipt indicates a marble headstone was purchased from Lewis L. Lewis Wholesale Dealer in Foreign and American Marbles, 21 and 23 Bleeker St., Utica. The receipt is made out a Mr. W. D. Roberts and is dated 1863-07-22. The amount purchased is "1 Marble Headstone" for "$35-". The receipt notes that the payment was received.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Roberts' Welsh Medicamentum Broadside, 1830
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The black-and-white broadside is an advertisement for Dr. Roberts' medicine. The broadside indicates the benefits of his medicine, what it cures, and where it can be purchased. The medicine, "cures indigestion or despepsia, liver complaints, jaundice, cholic, fever & ague, dysentary, headache, loss of appetite, flatulence, hypochondria, hysterics, dropsy, & heartburn." The document indicates that M. Hitchcock acted as Dr. Roberts' agent. Dr. Roberts' medicines are "Sold in Albany by R.M. Meigs, Druggist 466 South Market-street."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Old Print Shop Farmers' Museum
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicines; Sick persons;
Business & Industry;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: broadside; b&w; 11 x 8 in. (27.94 x 20.32 cm.)
